ygData.subject: Re: Multiagent HyperNEAT Revisited

Subject: Re: Multiagent HyperNEAT Revisited

Hi Jeff,

Thanks for your interest in our paper.

In response to comments=
 1-3, we've actually run several preliminary experiments with the intent of=
 answering the questions you've asked.  We hope to have a publication with =
formal results based on those experiments soon.  In general though, we do f=
eel that this approach is superior to the one discussed in the previous mul=
tiagent HyperNEAT paper and would recommend anyone who wants to work with m=
ultiagent HyperNEAT to use the z-based substrate.

I'll respond in detail t=
o the remaining points.

4.  Way back when I first converted SharpNEAT to H=
yperSharpNEAT I tried a number of values and found that there wasn't a larg=
e difference between them, although 20% seemed to be slightly better.  For =
any new domains I'll try a few values to see if they make any difference, b=
ut I haven't found any where the elitism value made a significant differenc=
e.

I will say that I've never tried just saving the best organism.  One re=
ason is that the SharpNEAT speciation code isn't really designed to only sa=
ve one genome.  The other is that I think saving at least the best genomes =
in your best species would help prevent promising species from accidentally=
 dying off too early.  On the other hand, I know you have several successfu=
l HyperNEAT experiments, so I guess I'll turn the question back on you: Hav=
e you found saving just the best genome to generally be better than saving =
more?  I'm certainly willing to give it a try if you've seen much better re=
sults.

5.  The answer to whether we renormalize the sheets or insert the n=
ew sheets between the old is technically both.  In general we renormalize, =
that is however many agents there are, they are evenly spaced between -1 an=
d 1.  While it may seem like a good idea to leave the original sheets where=
 they were and insert the new ones among them, in most cases it is difficul=
t to determine where the new sheets should go.

For example, if there were =
5 agents located at z=3D{-1, -0.5, 0, 0.5, 1} and the team needed to be sca=
led to 7 agents, where should the two new agents go?  There are two agents,=
 but four spaces (-0.75, -0.25, 0.25, 0.75) to put them and no real reason =
to choose any of the spaces over the others.  By redistributing the agents =
evenly we eliminate such ad hoc decisions.  However, if the 5 agent team we=
re to be scaled up to 9 agents, they would be placed at z=3D{-1, -0.75, -0.=
5, -0.25, 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75,1}.  Thus, even though we're renormalizing, th=
e placement works out the same as if we had inserted the new agents among t=
he old.

6.  The sign function simply returns the sign of the node's activa=
tion: -1 if the activation is negative, 0 if it is 0, and 1 if it is positi=
ve.  The reason for this function and the starting structure is to establis=
h a team with mirror symmetry i.e. the ANN of the agent at z=3D 1 is the ho=
rizontally flipped version of the agent at z=3D-1 and so on.  We found that=
 team mirror symmetry was beneficial in both domains that were tested in th=
is paper, so it was logical to allow it to start with symmetry (which can b=
e broken or ignored with mutations).

I hope I've answered your questions,
=
David


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Con=
grats on this paper. It features a lot of nice results.
> 
> A few question=
s/comments:
> 
> 1) The issue of interpolation is extremely interesting. In=
 this paper you
> explicitly discuss how it would be beneficial to add new =
agents, and have
> their roles be intermediate versions of other agents (e.=
g., adding a 12th
> soccer player between the forwards and the midfielders =
would create a player
> that was a hybrid of the two roles). It would also =
be cool to see if teams
> can gracefully re-divide the strategy-space when =
they lose agents. For
> example, in soccer/futbol, after a few red cards ar=
e assigned, each player
> does not play the usual role that they would play=
 on a team of 11, but
> instead re-divide the space up amongst the fewer pl=
ayers. For example, after
> the red cards their may be a left and right for=
ward instead of a left, right
> and center forward. It would be cool to see=
 if you can see such a result
> using your method. 
> 
> 2) You mention the=
 benefits of interpolated roles, but do you have any
> evidence that such i=
nterpolation is occurring? One cool way to test this
> would be to compare =
two different treatments: T1) take your original N
> agents and multiply th=
em to achieve the desired scaled-up number of agents
> (e.g., 9, 25, 100, 1=
000). If you start with 10 agents, and scale to 1000,
> you thus get 100 id=
entical copies of agent 1, 100 identical copies of agent
> 2, etc. Compare =
the performance of this treatment to T2) interpolate 1000
> agents into the=
 z coordinate range, so you have 1000 slightly different
> agents. The diff=
erence in performance between these treatments will help you
> figure out w=
hether you are seeing a boost due to interpolation. If the
> performance in=
crease due to scaling is not different between T1 and T2, then
> you know y=
our performance boost was simply due to having more agents, not
> due to in=
terpolation (you note something similar when you say "adding more
> agents =
that all do the same thing will eventually cause a pile-up"...my
> suggesti=
on is a way to test this claim).
> 
> 3) Why do you feel this new technique=
 is better than your old technique? Is
> it possible to compare the two exp=
erimentally? Have you done so?
> 
> 4) I notice you mention that you use 20=
% elitism. I usually only save the
> best organism. Have you found 20% to w=
ork a lot better, generally?
> 
> 5) When you add new agents, do you leave =
the previous sheets in the same
> place, and interpolate new sheets between=
 them, or do you renormalize all of
> the sheets such that it may be the ca=
se that no new agent is in the exact z
> coordinate of one of the original =
agents? It might be interesting to try
> both and see which tends to work b=
etter.
> 
> 6) What is the 'sign' function you mention in Figure 2? In gene=
ral, I am
> having trouble figuring out what this means: "The starting stru=
cture of the
> initial heterogeneous CPPN (Figure 2b) includes some additio=
nal structure to
> start evolution with knowledge of mirrored team symmetry=
; in particular, the
> sign function of z connected to multiplication opera=
tors on the x-axis means
> that the CPPN knows which side of the team is wh=
ich and can opt to reflect
> one side across the midline."
> 
> Congrats ag=
ain on this nice work.
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evoluti=
on Lab, Michigan State University
> jclune@...
> www.msu.edu/~jclune
> 
>

>

> > Subject: [neat] Multiagent Hyp=
erNEAT Revisited
> > 
> > Our 2008 GECCO paper by David D'Ambrosio and myse=
lf introduced the idea that a
> > single HyperNEAT CPPN can encode a set of=
 neural networks (instead of just
> > one) that represent a pattern of poli=
cies for an entire team.  Since then a
> > few people have asked about the =
way we laid out the team on the substrate and
> > whether alternatives migh=
t be better.
> > 
> > I am happy to announce, with my co-authors David D'Am=
brosio, Joel Lehman, and
> > Sebastian Risi, that we have extensively teste=
d such an alternative
> > z-axis-based encoding and published the results t=
o appear in AAMAS 2010,
> > available here:
> > 
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.ed=
u/publications/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html
> > 
> > Direct Link: http://epl=
ex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_aamas10.pdf
> > 
> > We believe this z-based=
 substrate layout is superior to the previous one,
> > particularly for sca=
ling the size of the team, and should open up the field of
> > multiagent l=
earning further to HyperNEAT.  The paper also includes the first
> > publis=
hed results on scaling the size of the team without further training,
> > w=
hich works because HyperNEAT can interpolate new policies for ANNs inserted=

> > along the z axis of the substrate.
> > 
> > Videos that accompany the =
paper are here:
> > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/mahnaamas2010.html
> > 
> > ken=

> >
